page.title: 04THE CHURCH IN EAST MERSEA
page.content: St. Edmunds church is built of local flint and is situated in Church Lane. It is 600 years old and it took 200 years to build. It was originally a Catholic church but now it is Church of England. During the Catholic period a tower was built with 5 bells but now only one remains. The door to the tower is unusual in having three locks. It is thought locally that it was used for smugglins in the 17th. century as the three keys were held by different people. The church is well maintained with a large stained-glass window above the altar. The family box-pews have been replaced by chairs made by a local craftsman which can seat up to 80 people. There is a church service every Sunday at 9.30 and the average congregation is 35.
